history.content: I took 134 last semester after taking cs70. There was a lot of overlap up until the first midterm, which was on discrete probability. Almost everything after that was new content (but there was still a little overlap for basic continuous probability). IMO it's still worth taking because I still learned a lot of new things and got a more solid understanding of probability concepts.

children.subject: (I've TA'ed for 70 before and am familiar with both classes)
What alternatives do I have to STAT 134 for the STAT major? Do they accept EE 126?

^ You should probably ask the stats people. Also, for what it's worth, in general just the fact that two courses "cover" the same topics does not mean the depth is the same. 70 is a very light introduction to probability. For example, if you flip open any book/notes on advanced probability, you will see the same topics (independence, Markov chains, expectation, etc), but the actual content is well beyond the scope of 70. While this may not be the case for 134 (depending on who you ask), it might be worth keeping in mind.
I actually think so -- that it's kinda pointless after taking 70.

history.content:
Stat 134 description:

An introduction to probability, emphasizing concepts and applications. Conditional expectation, independence, laws of large numbers. Discrete and continuous random variables. Central limit theorem. Selected topics such as the Poisson process, Markov chains, characteristic functions.

All of this material is covered in CS 70 except Characteristic functions. I have to take STAT 134 to declare Stats major. Do I have any better options?
history.subject: Stat 134 useless if I took CS 70?
